comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: A-6A Intruder 151780 flying at medium height above broken cumulo nimbus cloud layer. Radome painted black with airframe in gull gray & white scheme. Squadron Modex code number 400 on side of nose below windshield. VA-85 on rear fuselage aft of national insignia and front of underwing external fuel tank. Script USS ENTERPRISE over word 'NAVY' Code AE of Carrier Air Wing Six on tail (CVW-6). Rudder decorated in red with what appears to be small white stars in vertical arrangement. CVW-6 aircraft are not recorded as being assigned to CVN-65 USS Enterprise. VA-85 'Black Falcons' only served with CVW-6 during a 1968 deployment aboard CVA-66 USS America. There is a 1965-1966 record for A-6A 151780 with VA-85: www.gonavy.jp/CVW11-NH1965.html A-6A 151780 is recorded with VA-85 'Black Falcons' as Modex 800. This was with Carrier Air Wing Eleven (CVW-11 using code NH) when embarked on CVA-63 USS KITTY HAWK from October 19, 1965 to June 13, 1966 for a Western Pacific & Vietnam War deployment. Despite being listed with VA-85 for the deployment, A-6A Intruder 151780 was lost on Tuesday 27 July 1965 with one other before it was able to enter active service: (being a nearly new aircraft from the 1964/1965 production batch) www.ejection-history.org.uk/aircraft_by_type/a6_prowler.htm A-6A Intruder 151780 was involved in a tragic mid air collision with BuNo 151786 during a formation join-up off the coast of California 75 miles west of San Diego during work ups on USS Kitty Hawk prior to leaving for the Western Pacific - which would have been the aircrafts first deployment. Pilot; Lieutenant Junior Grade G. F. Wagner ejected Bombardier/Navigator; Lieutenant A. Malinkoff ejected - missing**. (use slider on right to scroll down to entry in chronological order)

comment.author: 16797445@N04
comment._content:
The squadron wore identical markings during its 1968 cruise aboard USS America, except wearing the new white/cream neoprene radome coating, and 5xx modes series numbers.
It was not uncommon for Navy jets to be assigned to an Air Wing and carrier, and the for the cruise to be scrubbed or switched to meet operational requirements, hence the mkgs above are a bit of a fiction, although real in the sense they were applied.
E.g. VMFA-451 never deployed on the Forrestal 76-77 although their F-4Js wore AA codes and were marked USS Forrestal for a while!
